Yes, the Vikings' use of hot stones for cleansing their skin was similar to the way we use steam rooms or saunas today. Viking saunas, known as "sweat houses," were small huts made of wood or stone. They were heated using hot stones, which would then be sprinkled with water to create steam.

Inside the sweat house, Vikings would undress and sit on benches around the perimeter of the room. The heat and steam would cause them to sweat, which would help to cleanse the skin and open up pores. Afterward, they would cool off by jumping into a nearby lake or river or by rolling in the snow.

While Viking saunas were primarily used for hygiene purposes, they were also considered to have spiritual and social significance. They were seen as a place for purification and reconciliation, and were often used as a gathering place for friends and family.

Overall, Viking saunas were an important part of their hygiene and wellness practices, as well as an essential part of their cultural identity.
